repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
resolves https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33497

Current progress:
1. `gx` will follow documentLink if available
2. 'goto file' actions like `gf` and `CTRL-W_CTRL-F` will follow documentLink as second try via `vim.lsp.includeexpr`.
3. `vim.lsp.buf.documentLink` opens a loctionlist like document symbols.
4. suports multiple clients. try [this dummy lsp](https://github.com/neo451/dot/blob/main/nvim/.config/nvim/lua/lsp/dummy.lua) with gopls on a go file :)

todoï¼š
- [ ] test

As a reference, vscode has one keymap Ctrl-Click for both internal path and urls, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33497 mentioned something like RightClick or Shift-Click

comment_data.body: I don't think we need to expose this. Because of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25272 I think we shouldn't be adding more stuff to `vim.lsp.util`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2320,6 +2326,20 @@ get_effective_tabstop({bufnr})          *vim.lsp.util.get_effective_tabstop()*
     See also: ~
       â€¢ 'shiftwidth'
 
+                                               *vim.lsp.util.links_to_items()*

comment_data.body: What's the point of adding a method that's deprecated out of the bat? @lewis6991 understands the logic here better but I don't think we need to add another handler.

Nit:
```suggestion
        lnum = range.start.line + 1
```
We need to use `range['end']` because `end` is a Lua keyword.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1840,6 +1840,59 @@ function M.symbols_to_items(symbols, bufnr, position_encoding)
   return items
 end
 
+--- Converts links to quickfix list items.
+---
+---@param links lsp.DocumentLink[]
+---@param bufnr? integer buffer handle or 0 for current, defaults to current
+---@param position_encoding? 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'
+---                         default to first client of buffer
+---@return vim.quickfix.entry[] # See |setqflist()| for the format
+function M.links_to_items(links, bufnr, position_encoding)
+  bufnr = vim._resolve_bufnr(bufnr)
+  if position_encoding == nil then
+    vim.notify_once(
+      'links_to_items must be called with valid position encoding',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+    position_encoding = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = 0 })[1].offset_encoding
+  end
+
+  local items = {} --- @type vim.quickfix.entry[]
+  for _, link in ipairs(links) do
+    --- @type string?, lsp.Range?
+    local uri, range = link.target, link.range
+    if uri and range then
+      ---@type integer?, integer?, integer?, integer?
+      local lnum, col, end_lnum, end_col
+
+      ---@type string, string
+      local filename, text
+      if vim.startswith(uri, 'file:///') then
+        filename = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
+        text = filename
+      else
+        filename = vim.uri_to_fname(vim.uri_from_bufnr(bufnr))
+        text = uri
+        lnum = range['start'].line + 1

comment_data.body: You can pass a method to `get_clients` so that it returns clients that support the given method.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -173,6 +173,27 @@ function M.open(path, opt)
   return vim.system(cmd, job_opt), nil
 end
 
+--- Return the first client attached that supports `textDocument/documentLink`, if any.
+---@param buf integer
+---@return vim.lsp.Client?
+local function buf_support_document_link(buf)
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local clients = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = bufnr })

comment_data.body: Instead of hardcoding the method names use `vim.lsp.protocol.Methods`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -173,6 +173,27 @@ function M.open(path, opt)
   return vim.system(cmd, job_opt), nil
 end
 
+--- Return the first client attached that supports `textDocument/documentLink`, if any.
+---@param buf integer
+---@return vim.lsp.Client?
+local function buf_support_document_link(buf)
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local clients = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = bufnr })
+  return vim.iter(clients):find(function(client)
+    return client:supports_method('textDocument/documentLink', buf)

comment_data.body: Same comment here about using `vim.lsp.protocol.Methods`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -182,6 +203,26 @@ function M._get_urls()
   local cursor = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
   local row = cursor[1] - 1
   local col = cursor[2]
+
+  local document_link_client = buf_support_document_link(bufnr)
+
+  if document_link_client then
+    local params = { textDocument = vim.lsp.util.make_text_document_params(bufnr) }
+    local position =
+      vim.lsp.util.make_position_params(0, document_link_client.offset_encoding).position
+
+    local buf_links =
+      document_link_client:request_sync('textDocument/documentLink', params, 1000, bufnr).result

comment_data.body: I don't see why we should limit this to a single client. We can send the request to all clients that support `documentLink` and process all the results.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   local row = cursor[1] - 1
   local col = cursor[2]
+
+  local document_link_client = buf_support_document_link(bufnr)

comment_data.body: FWIW, I think using the string as you've done here is better, and using the methods object has no benefit. If not already, `supports_method` can be type annotated so it only accepts the valid method values, so there is no risk of typos.

+  local clients = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = bufnr })
+  return vim.iter(clients):find(function(client)
+    return client:supports_method('textDocument/documentLink', buf)

comment_data.body: We should not add the handler here. It should be added to `buf.lua` and not exposed.
But we do use the enum in other places so at least let's keep the style consistency.

comment_data.body: I think using the object is more fair, not for more concrete reason, just because I did mistyped it when implementing and saw a lot of RPC errors not knowing what is going on. It will signal to more first time contributors like me to get the name right and avoid confusion maybe?

ok

comment_data.body: All the other `response_to_list` handlers need to be rewritten to handle multiple servers anyway.
I think you should map to `:normal! gf` instead of `:edit <cfile>`, so that it can take advantage of filetype `'includeexpr'` and `'suffixesadd'` as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +165,25 @@ do
     end, { desc = gx_desc })
   end
 
+  --- Map |gf| to call `vim.cmd.edit` on the <cfile> or `textDocument/documentLink` at cursor.

comment_data.body: I tried but I don't think `gf` takes an argument?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +165,25 @@ do
     end, { desc = gx_desc })
   end
 
+  --- Map |gf| to call `vim.cmd.edit` on the <cfile> or `textDocument/documentLink` at cursor.

comment_data.body:
Sorry, I mean like if it cannot find a valid path with `_get_urls()`, it could also try `:normal gf!`.

But I'm also not sure whether that is necessary, because maybe LSP could replace ftplugin's includeexpr. If that's the case, I guess it's better to just modifying `'includeexpr'`? That would save you from having to remap all of `gf`, `gF`, `<C-w><C-f>`
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: Nit: Shouldn't this be indented under the first bullet point?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -133,6 +133,12 @@ HIGHLIGHTS
 LSP
 
 â€¢ |vim.lsp.ClientConfig| gained `workspace_required`.
+â€¢ Support for `textDocument/documentLink`: |lsp-buf|
+    https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_documentLink
+- `vim.lsp.buf.documentLink()` lists all links in the document

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the <cfile> or `textDocument/documentLink` under the cursor.
```
Why not handle errors (the first argument)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   request_with_opts(ms.textDocument_documentSymbol, params, opts)
 end
 
+---
+--- The returned function has an optional {config} parameter that accepts |vim.lsp.ListOpts|
+---
+---@param map_result fun(resp, bufnr: integer, position_encoding: 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'): table to convert the response
+---@param entity string name of the resource used in a `not found` error message
+---@param title_fn fun(ctx: lsp.HandlerContext): string Function to call to generate list title
+---@return lsp.Handler
+local function response_to_list(map_result, entity, title_fn)
+  --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:redundant-parameter
+  return function(_, result, ctx, config)

comment_data.body:
Nit: This module sets `local lsp = vim.lsp`, so might as well use the variable.
```suggestion
    local client = assert(lsp.get_client_by_id(ctx.client_id))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,6 +813,118 @@ function M.document_symbol(opts)
   request_with_opts(ms.textDocument_documentSymbol, params, opts)
 end
 
+---
+--- The returned function has an optional {config} parameter that accepts |vim.lsp.ListOpts|
+---
+---@param map_result fun(resp, bufnr: integer, position_encoding: 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'): table to convert the response
+---@param entity string name of the resource used in a `not found` error message
+---@param title_fn fun(ctx: lsp.HandlerContext): string Function to call to generate list title
+---@return lsp.Handler
+local function response_to_list(map_result, entity, title_fn)
+  --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:redundant-parameter
+  return function(_, result, ctx, config)
+    if not result or vim.tbl_isempty(result) then
+      vim.notify('No ' .. entity .. ' found')
+      return
+    end
+    config = config or {}
+    local title = title_fn(ctx)
+    local client = assert(vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(ctx.client_id))

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    position_encoding = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = bufnr })[1].offset_encoding
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,6 +813,118 @@ function M.document_symbol(opts)
   request_with_opts(ms.textDocument_documentSymbol, params, opts)
 end
 
+---
+--- The returned function has an optional {config} parameter that accepts |vim.lsp.ListOpts|
+---
+---@param map_result fun(resp, bufnr: integer, position_encoding: 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'): table to convert the response
+---@param entity string name of the resource used in a `not found` error message
+---@param title_fn fun(ctx: lsp.HandlerContext): string Function to call to generate list title
+---@return lsp.Handler
+local function response_to_list(map_result, entity, title_fn)
+  --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:redundant-parameter
+  return function(_, result, ctx, config)
+    if not result or vim.tbl_isempty(result) then
+      vim.notify('No ' .. entity .. ' found')
+      return
+    end
+    config = config or {}
+    local title = title_fn(ctx)
+    local client = assert(vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(ctx.client_id))
+    local items = map_result(result, ctx.bufnr, client.offset_encoding)
+
+    local list = { title = title, items = items, context = ctx }
+    if config.on_list then
+      assert(vim.is_callable(config.on_list), 'on_list is not a function')
+      config.on_list(list)
+    elseif config.loclist then
+      vim.fn.setloclist(0, {}, ' ', list)
+      vim.cmd.lopen()
+    else
+      vim.fn.setqflist({}, ' ', list)
+      vim.cmd('botright copen')
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+--- Converts links to quickfix list items.
+---
+---@param links lsp.DocumentLink[]
+---@param bufnr? integer buffer handle or 0 for current, defaults to current
+---@param position_encoding? 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'
+---                         default to first client of buffer
+---@return vim.quickfix.entry[] # See |setqflist()| for the format
+local function links_to_items(links, bufnr, position_encoding)
+  bufnr = vim._resolve_bufnr(bufnr)
+  if position_encoding == nil then
+    vim.notify_once(
+      'links_to_items must be called with valid position encoding',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+    position_encoding = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = 0 })[1].offset_encoding

comment_data.body:
I would replace this by an early return and use `lsp._unsupported_method`:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/9a07c141b2776c2a866a96d2e5625e7ff43a3a70/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/buf.lua#L167-L169
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   local row = cursor[1] - 1
   local col = cursor[2]
+
+  local document_link_clients =
+    vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = bufnr, method = ms.textDocument_documentLink })
+
+  if #document_link_clients ~= 0 then

comment_data.body: To support multiple clients this will either need to use `buf_request_all` and merge the results in some way or loop over `get_clients()` and make requests using `client:request` and merge the results via some countdown handling. See other methods in this file for examples.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,6 +813,118 @@ function M.document_symbol(opts)
   request_with_opts(ms.textDocument_documentSymbol, params, opts)
 end
 
+---
+--- The returned function has an optional {config} parameter that accepts |vim.lsp.ListOpts|
+---
+---@param map_result fun(resp, bufnr: integer, position_encoding: 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'): table to convert the response
+---@param entity string name of the resource used in a `not found` error message
+---@param title_fn fun(ctx: lsp.HandlerContext): string Function to call to generate list title
+---@return lsp.Handler
+local function response_to_list(map_result, entity, title_fn)
+  --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:redundant-parameter
+  return function(_, result, ctx, config)
+    if not result or vim.tbl_isempty(result) then
+      vim.notify('No ' .. entity .. ' found')
+      return
+    end
+    config = config or {}
+    local title = title_fn(ctx)
+    local client = assert(vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(ctx.client_id))
+    local items = map_result(result, ctx.bufnr, client.offset_encoding)
+
+    local list = { title = title, items = items, context = ctx }
+    if config.on_list then
+      assert(vim.is_callable(config.on_list), 'on_list is not a function')
+      config.on_list(list)
+    elseif config.loclist then
+      vim.fn.setloclist(0, {}, ' ', list)
+      vim.cmd.lopen()
+    else
+      vim.fn.setqflist({}, ' ', list)
+      vim.cmd('botright copen')
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+--- Converts links to quickfix list items.
+---
+---@param links lsp.DocumentLink[]
+---@param bufnr? integer buffer handle or 0 for current, defaults to current
+---@param position_encoding? 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'
+---                         default to first client of buffer
+---@return vim.quickfix.entry[] # See |setqflist()| for the format
+local function links_to_items(links, bufnr, position_encoding)
+  bufnr = vim._resolve_bufnr(bufnr)
+  if position_encoding == nil then
+    vim.notify_once(
+      'links_to_items must be called with valid position encoding',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+    position_encoding = vim.lsp.get_clients({ bufnr = 0 })[1].offset_encoding
+  end
+
+  local items = {} --- @type vim.quickfix.entry[]
+  for _, link in ipairs(links) do
+    --- @type string?, lsp.Range?
+    local uri, range = link.target, link.range
+    if uri and range then
+      ---@type integer?, integer?, integer?, integer?
+      local lnum, col, end_lnum, end_col
+
+      ---@type string, string
+      local filename, text
+      if vim.startswith(uri, 'file:///') then
+        filename = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
+        text = filename
+      else
+        filename = vim.uri_to_fname(vim.uri_from_bufnr(bufnr))
+        text = uri
+        lnum = range.start.line + 1
+        col = util.character_offset(
+          bufnr,
+          range.start.line,
+          range.start.character,
+          position_encoding
+        ) + 1
+        end_lnum = range['end'].line + 1
+        end_col = util.character_offset(
+          bufnr,
+          range['end'].line,
+          range['end'].character,
+          position_encoding
+        ) + 1
+      end
+
+      items[#items + 1] = {
+        filename = filename,
+        lnum = lnum or 1,
+        col = col or 1,
+        end_lnum = end_lnum or 1,
+        end_col = end_col or 1,
+        text = text,
+      }
+    end
+  end
+
+  return items
+end
+
+--- Lists all links in the current buffer in the |location-list|.
+--- @param opts? vim.lsp.ListOpts
+function M.document_link(opts)
+  opts = vim.tbl_deep_extend('keep', opts or {}, { loclist = true })
+  local params = { textDocument = util.make_text_document_params() }
+
+  local handler = response_to_list(links_to_items, 'document links', function(ctx)
+    local fname = vim.fn.fnamemodify(vim.uri_to_fname(ctx.params.textDocument.uri), ':.')
+    return string.format('Links in %s', fname)
+  end)
+
+  lsp.buf_request(0, ms.textDocument_documentLink, params, function(err, result, ctx, config)
+    handler(err, result, ctx, vim.tbl_extend('force', config or {}, opts))
+  end)

comment_data.body: not sure about that, gx is not equal to calling the lsp funcitonality, so warning seems no need, and it has a natural fallback (cfile), early return will make gx behave differently if I am not mistaken about what you mean

+---
+--- The returned function has an optional {config} parameter that accepts |vim.lsp.ListOpts|
+---
+---@param map_result fun(resp, bufnr: integer, position_encoding: 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'): table to convert the response
+---@param entity string name of the resource used in a `not found` error message

comment_regular_data.body:
> The issue now is following local filepath, should we also use add this additional ability to gf?

As a user I'd love it, but I hope it will fall back to default `gf` if the cursor is not on `documentLink`

> I'd love it, but I hope it will fall back to default `gf` if the cursor is not on `documentLink`

Yes it is very reasonable to do the fallback and the `vim.ui_get_urls` function is already falls back to `<cfile>` now.

I am not sure if calling `vim.cmd.edit` on the result of `vim.ui_get_urls`, is correct way to go with this. It does properly fallback to opening normal file paths. But I don't know if `gf` has more other behaviors that I don't know.

the docs says something I don't understand:

> 	If you do want to edit a new file, use: 
		:e \<cfile\>
>     To make gf always work like that: 
				:map gf :e \<cfile\>\<CR\>

That make my question my original understanding of `gf`. What am I missing?

And should related keybinds like `gF` and `CTRL-W_CTRL-F` be modified as well? That seems too much for me though.
